results.abstract: An ensemble cast aims to bring comedy and adventure to this film made in the image of the popular role-playing game.

results.title: ‘A Thousand and One’ Review: A New York Love Story
results.abstract: A mesmerizing Teyana Taylor stars in A.V. Rockwell’s feature directing debut, about motherhood and survival in a fast-changing city.

multimedia.caption: Played by a mesmerizing Teyana Taylor, Inez holds you rapt throughout a sweeping New York story of love and survival, motherhood and gentrification.

results.abstract: Like its namesake, this film is clever, crafty and shockingly entertaining.

results.title: Teyana Taylor’s Pivot to Acting: ‘It Was a Real-Life Faith Walk’
results.abstract: After stepping away from recording music, the artist has turned to movies with a lead role in “A Thousand and One.”

multimedia.caption: Teyana Taylor didn’t yet land her role in “A Thousand and One” before retiring from music, she said, “so it was a real-life faith walk.”

results.title: ‘Kill Boksoon’ Review: It’s a Deadly Job for a Busy Single Mom
results.abstract: An assassin must choose between the murderous career she loves and the daughter she’s been hiding it from.

results.title: Why Tetris Consumed Your Brain
results.abstract: Tetris exploded in popularity after a race in the 1980s to secure global rights for the Soviet-made video game, a tale retold in a new movie. It is still captivating minds decades later.

results.title: A Movie Confronts Germany’s Other Genocide
results.abstract: “Measures of Men” tells the story of the systematic massacre of Herero and Nama people in what is now Namibia. Its maker hopes the film will bring a debate about Germany’s colonial guilt into the center of society.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Leonard Scheicher, left, and Girley Jazama in “Measures of Men,” which tells the story of the Herero and Nama genocide in what now Namibia through the eyes of a German anthropologist.
Leonard Scheicher, left, and Girley Jazama in “Measures of Men,” which tells the story of the Herero and Nama genocide in what now Namibia through the eyes of a German anthropologist.
Leonard Scheicher, left, and Girley Jazama in “Measures of Men,” which tells the story of the Herero and Nama genocide in what now Namibia through the eyes of a German anthropologist.

results.title: Michael Blackwood, Who Captured 20th-Century Artists on Film, Dies at 88
results.abstract: He made cinéma vérité documentaries — more than 160 — about musicians (Thelonious Monk), architects (Frank Gehry), composers (Philip Glass) and sculptors (Isamu Noguchi).

multimedia.caption: Michael Blackwood in 1975. “His priority wasn’t making an art piece,” his son said, “but to make a film about the art his camera was capturing.”
Michael Blackwood in 1975. “His priority wasn’t making an art piece,” his son said, “but to make a film about the art his camera was capturing.”
Michael Blackwood in 1975. “His priority wasn’t making an art piece,” his son said, “but to make a film about the art his camera was capturing.”

results.title: ‘In Viaggio: The Travels of Pope Francis’ Review: Serene Demeanor, Bracing Message
results.abstract: The Pontiff travels well. Gianfranco Rosi’s new documentary chronicles his visits to Catholic communities the world over, and he never seems to tire.
des_facet: In Viaggio: The Travels of Pope Francis (Movie)

multimedia.caption: In his first nine years as Pope, Francis visited almost 60 countries. Gianfranco Rosi’s documentary features footage shot over those years.

results.title: Disney Lays Off Ike Perlmutter, Chairman of Marvel Entertainment

results.title: Ari Aster Has Something Funny to Show You. Don’t Be Scared.
results.abstract: The maker of “Midsommar” may be known for horror, but he thought that film was comical. With his latest movie, “Beau Is Afraid,” the dark humor is more apparent.

multimedia.caption: Ari Aster initially intended “Beau Is Afraid” to be his first film. Instead he spent time during the pandemic lockdown honing the script into an uncompromising follow-up to “Midsommar.”
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
